statement:
If $a$ and $b$ are arbitrary elements of the group $(G,*)$, then the
inverse of $a*b$ is $$\begin{aligned}
      (a*b)^{-1} = b^{-1}*a^{-1}.\end{aligned}$$

[*Proof.*]{} Let the neutral element of the group, which may be proved
unique, be $e$. Using only the group postulates we obtain
$$(a*b)*(b^{-1}*a^{-1}) = a*(b*(b^{-1}*a^{-1})) = 
a*((b*b^{-1})*a^{-1}) = a*(e*a^{-1}) = a*a^{-1} = e,$$
$$(b^{-1}*a^{-1})*(a*b) = b^{-1}*(a^{-1}*(a*b)) = b^{-1}*((a^{-1}*a)*b) = 
b^{-1}*(e*b) = b^{-1}*b = e,$$ Q.E.D.

**Note.** The (1) may be by induction extended to the form
$$(a_1*\cdots*a_n)^{-1} = a_n^{-1}*\cdots*a_1^{-1}.$$
names: inverse of a product in group
